results.title: A Step from the shadows
results.creator_credit: Gary Lindberg, James Michael and Russell Manning Productions
results.brief_description: Two children hear their parents arguing. The mother, an alcoholic, will not admit that she has a problem. Eventually her husband goes to a doctor who suggests possible ways of tackling the illness. The first attempt at rehabilitation fails, but finally, after admitting that she is ill, she appears to be on the way to controlling her disease.

results.title: A Share in their tomorrow
results.brief_description: How a group of British companies are assisting, by aerial surveys, the Sudan Government to open up and develop unproductive, and previously inaccessible, terrain in the Sudan. The valuable contribution of the helicopter for surveying purposes is illustrated.

results.title: A Sense of the other (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Dana H. Hodgdon, Frank Galati, Bernice Gregorio and Northwestern University
results.brief_description: Shows how old English literature, such as Shakespeare, can be studied through the medium of interpretation. This is understanding the text through performing and acting out the parts, by students. Shows performances, and also discusses with students and lecturers, the value of this method of study.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dana H. Hodgdon, Frank Galati, Bernice Gregorio and Northwestern University

results.title: A Secret place
results.creator_credit: Kim Cardow, Susan Jones, Nicholas Oughton and College of Art
results.brief_description: Shows the outdoor play environment at the Lady Gowrie Child Centre in Brisbane where children can take advantage of conditions not always available. Tree-houses, streams, mud pools and a variety of animals combine to make this natural environment. Shows how children can interact with even the simplest part of this environment.

results.title: The Darra dogs
results.brief_description: Haunted by the dogs of his childhood, Dennis Tupicoff tries to explain his feelings about dogs to his 4 year old daughter. Dennis and his brothers grew up in Darra, then an industrial suburb of Brisbane where every household seemed to have a dog. Some were friends who shared their lives and explorations while others were “hounds from hell” prowling though the neighbourhood. The Darra Dogs is a memorial to the mortal terrors of childhood, the sadness of death and loss and, of course, to the dogs themselves.
